summary: an outbreak of acute febrile illness occurred in the Republic of Korea boot camp from may to July 2011. a multiplex reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay was performed to identify possible causative factors. the main symptoms were sore throat (76.0%), sputum (72.8%), cough (72.1%), tonsillar hypertrophy (67.9%), and rhinorrhea (55.9%). acute febrile respiratory illness occurred collectively in a group of patients in a boot camp of the Republic of Korea Air Force (ROKAF) from may 2011 to July 2011. acute febrile respiratory illness occurred collectively in a group of patients in a boot camp. twenty-two patients were admitted to the hospital with cardinal symptoms of respiratory tract infection. thoat swab was carried out by smearing the posterior aspect of the pharynx with a sterile cotton swab while the tongue was pressed down with a tongue depressor. Statistical Analysis Subjects classified into four groups depending on the type of hospital treatment they received. the Kruskal-Wallis test and the analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) were used to find differences in body temperature and duration of fever among the groups. the throat swab samples collected from 5 patients were sent to the Seoul Clinical Laboratories and Seoul Medical Science Institute for analysis. a retrospective investigation for all 588 patients was conducted using computerrecorded patient charts. the clinical characteristics of the disease and types of therapeutic regimens were obtained from these records. acute febrile illness occurred collectively among military recruits starting from may 26, 2011. a rapid antigen test, an immunofluorescence assay, and a multiplex RT-PCR assay were carried out for all 11 patients with early onset of fever. the incidence of acute febrile disease continued for approximately two months, but it ceased after July 27, 2011. the peak occurrence was observed on June 16, 2011, when as many as 30 new patients were admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of fever.
